childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1965-1977

The smell of Coppertone sunscreen and fresh-cut grass. The crackle of a Swanson TV dinner being pulled from the oven. The weight of a View-Master against your face, clicking through reels of Grand Canyon vistas. Your childhood had a texture that was half Leave It to Beaver reruns and half Vietnam body counts at dinner—innocence and chaos sharing the same screen.

At four, you watched Neil Armstrong walk on the moon. Your family probably gathered around a black-and-white Zenith or RCA, tin foil on the antenna, watching grainy footage of something impossible becoming real. You didn't fully understand it, but you understood the adults were crying, and that meant it mattered.

Your toys were built to last. GI Joe with his kung-fu grip. Etch A Sketch that you could never quite master. Hot Wheels tracks that snaked through the living room. Lite-Brite creating glowing pictures in the dark. Spirograph making patterns you pretended were profound. Creepy Crawlers with that burning-rubber smell from the Thingmaker oven that would never pass safety standards today.

Saturday mornings were sacred. Scooby-Doo, Where Are You! at seven. The Banana Splits at eight. Land of the Lost with its claymation dinosaurs. Fat Albert and the Cosby Kids teaching lessons while you ate Super Sugar Crisp straight from the box. You had maybe seven channels if you were lucky—three networks, PBS, and whatever else the antenna could pull in. You were the remote control. 'Change it to Channel 4' meant getting off the couch.

School meant mimeographed worksheets with that purple ink smell. SRA Reading Labs with color-coded cards. Filmstrips with the beep that told you to advance. The Weekly Reader delivered news you could understand. Scholastic Book Club order forms that made you feel rich choosing between Encyclopedia Brown and The Great Brain.

Dinner was hamburger five ways—meatloaf Monday, spaghetti Tuesday, tacos from a box on Friday. Pop-Tarts and Tang for breakfast because astronauts drank Tang. Swanson TV dinners on special nights, the turkey one with the apple cobbler compartment that was always too hot. Kool-Aid by the pitcher. Wonder Bread because your mom saw the commercial.

At ten, you watched Saigon fall on the evening news. Helicopters evacuating the embassy, desperate people clinging to skids. Your parents had been arguing about this war your whole life, and now it was just... over. America had lost. That wasn't supposed to happen. Something fundamental shifted, though you wouldn't have the words for it until later.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Gen X

Gen X. The label came later—Douglas Coupland's 1991 novel gave you a name after you'd already become who you were. Before that, you were just the kids who came after the Boomers, the ones who grew up in their shadow, the ones who would never match their numbers or their noise.

You were seven when Nixon resigned. You watched it on television—a president admitting defeat, leaving in disgrace, flashing that weird double-V from the helicopter steps. Your parents had strong opinions. You absorbed the lesson before you could articulate it: authority figures lie, institutions fail, trust is earned, not given.

Your generation—roughly 65 million Americans born between 1965 and 1980—is the smallest of the major cohorts. Sandwiched between 76 million Boomers and 72 million Millennials, you're demographically invisible. Politicians don't court your vote. Marketers don't study your preferences. You're used to being overlooked. You've made it work for you.

They called you slackers in the '90s, which missed the point entirely. You weren't lazy—you just refused to perform enthusiasm for a game you could see was rigged. Your Boomer parents had preached idealism and then sold out for stock options and corner offices. You decided authenticity mattered more than advancement. Ironic detachment wasn't apathy; it was armor.

Latchkey was your lifestyle before it had a name. Both parents worked, or one parent was gone entirely. You came home to an empty house, made yourself a snack, did your homework without supervision, figured things out. By the time helicopter parenting became the norm, you'd already raised yourself. Self-reliance wasn't a virtue—it was survival.

You're the last fully analog generation. You remember card catalogs and encyclopedias. You learned to read maps and memorize phone numbers. You know what it feels like to be truly unreachable, to have hours pass without anyone knowing where you were. The internet arrived when you were already formed, which means you adapted to it rather than being shaped by it. You can still entertain yourself without a screen. That's a superpower now.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

The Sound of Music was the biggest movie the year you were born—Julie Andrews spinning on that Austrian mountaintop, nuns solving problems with song. The Beatles released Help! and Rubber Soul. Bob Dylan went electric at Newport and got booed by folk purists who couldn't see the future standing right in front of them. James Brown invented funk with 'Papa's Got a Brand New Bag.' The British Invasion was reshaping American music, and Motown was answering back with the Supremes, the Temptations, Marvin Gaye.

Your TV childhood was a mix of syndicated reruns and new shows testing boundaries. I Dream of Jeannie premiered the year you were born—Barbara Eden in that pink harem outfit that your dad noticed more than he should have. Get Smart made spies funny. Lost in Space sent a family to the stars. These shows were still on when you were old enough to watch them.

At five, you discovered Sesame Street—Big Bird, Oscar the Grouch, Gordon and Susan on that brownstone stoop. It was the first show that treated you like you had a brain. At six, Mister Rogers told you he liked you just the way you were, and part of you still believes him.

You were ten when Jaws kept everyone out of the water. Twelve when Star Wars created the modern blockbuster—you probably saw it multiple times that summer, waiting in lines that wrapped around the building, memorizing dialogue, playing with Kenner action figures before they even arrived in stores because you had the early bird certificate. That first glimpse of a Star Destroyer filling the screen, Princess Leia hiding the plans, Darth Vader's breath—you remember exactly where you sat.

Disco dominated your middle school years. 'Stayin' Alive' at every school dance. Saturday Night Fever taught you that a white suit and pointing at the ceiling was somehow cool. Then you were fourteen when disco died at Comiskey Park—a crate of vinyl records blown up between games of a doubleheader, a riot following, and suddenly admitting you'd liked disco became social suicide.

Punk arrived as the antidote. The Ramones, the Sex Pistols, the Clash—raw, fast, confrontational, everything disco wasn't. Then MTV launched when you were sixteen, and suddenly you could see music, not just hear it. New wave, synth-pop, early hip-hop—your high school years were a genre explosion. Michael Jackson's Thriller. Prince's Purple Rain. Madonna's Like a Virgin. You watched these artists define an era in real time.

Your pop culture was monoculture. Everyone watched the same shows, heard the same songs, quoted the same movies. When M*A*S*H ended in 1983, 105 million people watched. You were one of them. That kind of shared cultural moment doesn't exist anymore.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

The year you were born, Early Bird became the first commercial communications satellite and Gordon Moore predicted that transistor density would double every two years—a law that would define the next six decades. But your childhood was analog, mechanical, physical. Technology meant a transistor radio and a rotary phone with a curly cord that stretched to the bathroom for privacy.

Your family television was probably still black and white until you were four or five. Color was a luxury—an RCA or Zenith console that sat in the living room like furniture. You were the remote control. Channel changers didn't exist yet, and when they did arrive, your parents didn't trust them. 'Just get up and change it.'

At seven, Pong arrived. A black-and-white blip bouncing between two paddles—and it felt like the future. At twelve, you saw the Apple II, though your family probably didn't own one. Computers were for hobbyists and businesses. At fourteen, the Atari 2600 brought video games home, and suddenly Space Invaders and Asteroids were available in your living room, not just arcades.

The Walkman arrived when you were fourteen—Sony's portable cassette player that let you take your music anywhere. You could jog, ride the bus, walk to school with your own private soundtrack. The headphones were orange foam. The tapes wore out from rewinding your favorite songs. This was personal technology before it had a name.

At twenty, the Macintosh introduced the graphical user interface to the masses. At twenty-four, Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web, though you wouldn't use it for years. At thirty, Amazon launched. At thirty-two, Google. You didn't grow up with the internet—you watched it grow up around you. You remember what it was like before, which gives you perspective that younger generations lack.

You learned to type on a typewriter. Real keys, metal arms, correction ribbon. You wrote term papers with White-Out and carbon copies. When word processors arrived, they felt miraculous. When email replaced letters, you adapted. When smartphones replaced everything, you adapted again. You're the bridge generation—old enough to remember the analog world, young enough to have mastered the digital one. You can read a map, balance a checkbook, and troubleshoot a Wi-Fi network. Not everyone can claim all three.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were born into the middle of the Civil Rights era. The Voting Rights Act passed in August 1965, five months after Selma, four months before your birth. Malcolm X was assassinated in February. Watts erupted in August. The legal architecture of segregation was finally being demolished, though the social reality would take generations to shift.

At three, Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated on a Memphis balcony. Two months later, Robert Kennedy was shot in a Los Angeles hotel kitchen. 1968 was the year America came apart—riots, protests, violence, the Democratic convention in chaos. You don't remember it directly, but you grew up in its wreckage.

Vietnam was the background noise of your entire childhood. Walter Cronkite narrating footage of jungle firefights while your family ate dinner. Body counts announced like sports scores. At ten, you watched Saigon fall—helicopters evacuating the embassy, desperate crowds, the last Americans fleeing. Your country had lost a war. The adults who'd told you America always won had been wrong.

At nine, you watched Nixon resign. The Watergate hearings had been summer television—John Dean testifying, the tapes, the eighteen-and-a-half-minute gap. When Nixon finally gave up, flashing that double-V from the helicopter, you learned something about power that you've never unlearned: they lie. All of them.

At fourteen, the Iranian hostage crisis began—444 days of Americans held captive, Ted Koppel counting them nightly. At fifteen, Reagan was elected on a promise to restore American greatness. At eighteen, the Beirut barracks bombing killed 241 American servicemembers. Your coming-of-age happened against a backdrop of American vulnerability.

At twenty-four, the Berlin Wall fell. You were old enough to understand what it meant—the Cold War you'd grown up with, the nuclear anxiety, the duck-and-cover drills, all of it suddenly obsolete. At twenty-six, the Soviet Union collapsed entirely. The enemy you'd been trained to fear simply vanished.

At {{AGE_AT_911}}, you were {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} when the towers fell on 9/11. You probably had kids by then, or were about to. You watched the second plane hit live, just like everyone else, and you understood immediately that the world was about to change in ways you couldn't predict. You'd lived through enough history to recognize a hinge point when you saw one.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You entered the workforce in the mid-1980s, right when the rules changed. Reagan-era economics meant deregulation, union-busting, and the beginning of the great divergence between productivity and wages. The old social contract—work hard, stay loyal, retire with a pension—was being shredded in real time. You just didn't know it yet.

Your parents' career path looked like this: get hired at twenty-two, work forty years at the same company, get a pension and a gold watch, retire at sixty-two. Your path looked different from the start. You changed jobs every few years because that was the only way to get a raise. Loyalty got you laid off; mobility got you ahead. The company owed you nothing. You learned to owe them nothing back.

Corporate downsizing was the soundtrack of your thirties. 'Rightsizing,' they called it, as if there was a correct size and your job wasn't part of it. You watched executives get bonuses while your colleagues got boxes. You learned to keep your resume updated, your network active, your options open. Job security became an oxymoron.

The dot-com boom hit when you were in your early thirties. Some of you rode it up—stock options, IPOs, the fantasy that everyone would get rich clicking buttons. Some of you watched from the sidelines, suspicious of the hype, which turned out to be both smart and costly. The crash came in 2000, and suddenly all those options were worth nothing. Being skeptical didn't make you rich. Being lucky did.

At {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}}, the 2008 financial crisis arrived. You weren't young enough to start over easily. You weren't old enough to have accumulated enough wealth to weather it comfortably. You were stuck in the middle, watching your home value plummet, your 401(k) collapse, your job security evaporate. You rebuilt. What choice did you have?

Now you're the senior people—the managers, the directors, the executives. You're trying to lead Millennials who expect meaning from their work and Gen Z who expect flexibility from their schedules. You remember when showing up was the whole job. They work from coffee shops and expect mental health days. You're not sure who's right, so you try to meet them halfway. It doesn't always work.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You met people by accident. At parties. Through friends. At work. In bars. Dating meant working up the nerve to call someone's house and talking to their roommate or mother first. It meant picking them up at their door, shaking hands with their father, making small talk with the family before you could even leave. Romance required effort and courage in ways that apps have made obsolete.

Your first relationships happened without documentation. No texts to screenshot, no DMs to analyze, no social media to stalk. When it ended, it ended—no digital ghost haunting your feed. You learned to move on because there was no other option. The past stayed in the past because it had nowhere else to go.

You probably married in your late twenties or early thirties—later than your parents, earlier than Millennials. Your parents' generation had normalized divorce, so you weren't naive about marriage lasting forever. But you still believed in it, cautiously. You'd seen what didn't work. You tried to do better.

Communication technology evolved dramatically during your adult life. From landlines to answering machines to cell phones to smartphones. From letters to email to texting to the constant low-grade connection of always being reachable. You remember when being unavailable was normal. Now it's suspicious. 'Why didn't you text me back?' is a question that didn't exist in your twenties.

You're the last generation to have handwritten love letters tucked in a drawer somewhere. The last to have called someone just to hear their voice, not to convey information. The last to have experienced the agony of waiting by the phone, not knowing if they'd call. That anticipation—the hope and dread mixed together—is something younger generations will never know.

Your friendships are deep but not wide. You don't maintain hundreds of social media connections. You have a handful of people you'd actually call in a crisis—friends from high school, from college, from your twenties. You've known them longer than you've known your spouse. That history matters in ways that algorithm-generated connections can't replicate.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You entered the economy at an inflection point. The postwar boom was over. Inflation had been brutal in the late '70s. Interest rates were insane—mortgage rates hit 18% in the early '80s. Buying your first house meant paying more for money than for the house itself. Your financial life started on hard mode, which taught you lessons that never left.

Your generation caught the tail end of pensions and the beginning of the 401(k) era. If you were lucky, you got hired by a company that still offered defined benefits. If you weren't, you got a 401(k) and the advice to 'invest in mutual funds' without anyone explaining what that meant. The shift from employer responsibility to employee responsibility happened on your watch. You're still figuring out if you saved enough.

You bought your first house when they were still affordable—before the run-up that priced out Millennials, before the 2008 crash that wiped out equity, before housing became a financial instrument instead of a place to live. That timing wasn't skill; it was luck. But it's the difference between having something and having nothing.

Three major economic crashes hit during your prime earning years. The dot-com bust at thirty-five. The 2008 crisis at {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}}. COVID at {{AGE_AT_COVID}}. Each one taught the same lesson: stability is temporary, markets crash, nothing is guaranteed. You've learned to be diversified, skeptical, and prepared. You keep more cash on hand than financial advisors recommend because you've seen what happens when you can't access it.

Your relationship with money is pragmatic rather than optimistic. You save because you've seen what happens when you don't. You invest because inflation eats cash. You don't trust the system, but you participate because the alternative is worse. You're cynical enough to expect problems, practical enough to plan anyway.

Retirement is real now. You're doing the math constantly. Social Security might get cut before you collect. Healthcare costs are terrifying. The pension your father had—the gold watch, the defined benefit, the certainty—isn't available. You're trying to figure out if you have enough, and the answer keeps changing depending on what the market does. The anxiety doesn't go away; you just learn to live with it.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your skepticism served you well, but it can curdle into cynicism that prevents engagement. You're so convinced that systems are broken that you sometimes don't bother trying to fix them. 'Nothing ever changes' becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy when the people who believe it stop showing up. Ironic detachment was armor in your twenties; in your fifties, it can be a prison.

You have a tendency to dismiss younger generations as soft, entitled, or overly sensitive. The 'participation trophy' jokes got old a decade ago, but some of you are still making them. Millennials inherited a worse economy than you did. Gen Z faces a worse climate. Their challenges are different, not easier. Your condescension isn't earned, and it's not helping.

Your self-reliance can become isolation. You grew up learning to handle things yourself, not to burden others, to be independent. That made you capable but also bad at asking for help. You suffer in silence when you don't have to. Therapy was stigmatized when you were young; it's not anymore, but some of you still haven't gotten the message.

You can be technologically complacent. You adopted the internet, smartphones, and social media, but you did it as adults, after your habits were formed. Some of you stopped really adapting around 2010. TikTok feels foreign, Discord is confusing, AI is either overhyped or terrifying depending on the day. The digital landscape has changed dramatically, and not all of you have kept up.

Your relationship with activism is complicated. You grew up listening to Boomers talk endlessly about the '60s—the marches, the movements, the moment when they changed the world. Then you watched those same Boomers sell out for stock options. It made you suspicious of grand causes, of movement politics, of anyone who seemed too earnest. But the world still needs people who believe things can be better. Cynicism is comfortable. It's not useful.

You've spent so long being the forgotten generation that you've accepted invisibility as your role. Politicians don't court you. Marketers don't study you. You're sandwiched between larger cohorts that get all the attention. But invisible isn't the same as powerless. You're running things now—the senior executives, the experienced managers, the people who actually know how to get things done. Maybe it's time to stop being overlooked and start being heard.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (1985-1995): You entered the workforce during the Reagan-Bush era. The economy was growing but the rules were changing—downsizing, deregulation, the death of lifetime employment. You probably changed jobs several times before thirty, not out of restlessness but out of necessity. You learned to look out for yourself because no one else would. This was your decade of figuring out who you were while the old social contract was being burned.

Your 30s (1995-2005): The internet changed everything. You were young enough to adapt, old enough to have context. Some of you rode the dot-com wave up; the skeptics among you watched from the sidelines. Y2K turned out to be nothing. 9/11 turned out to be everything. By the end of this decade, you had mortgages, kids, responsibilities. The freedom of your twenties was gone. You were building something—a career, a family, a life—even when the ground kept shifting under you.

Your 40s (2005-2015): The 2008 crash hit you in the middle—not young enough to shrug it off, not old enough to have already accumulated real wealth. You spent years rebuilding what you'd lost. Your kids became teenagers, which brought its own challenges. Your parents started needing help. You were sandwiched—responsible for generations on both sides, pulling in every direction, exhausted in ways you couldn't explain. But you kept going. That's what you do.

Your 50s (2015-2025): You're in this decade now. These should be your peak earning years, but they're also peak expense years—college tuition, healthcare, maybe helping aging parents, definitely helping adult kids who can't afford rent in this economy. Retirement is visible on the horizon but not quite reachable. You're tired. You're also more certain than you've ever been about what matters and what doesn't. The anxieties of youth have been replaced by the anxieties of mortality. The tradeoff is unclear.

Your 60s (2025-2035): Retirement becomes real, whether you're ready or not. Some of you will retire early; most won't be able to afford it. Healthcare decisions get serious. Grandchildren might arrive. Your role shifts from doing to advising, from building to maintaining. The world belongs to younger people now. Your job is to let go gracefully, offer wisdom when asked, stay out of the way when not. It's harder than it sounds.

Your 70s and beyond (2035+): You'll have stories to tell about a world before the internet, before smartphones, before everything changed. Whether anyone wants to hear them is another question. The generations you raised will be running things—hopefully better than the ones before. Aging isn't for the faint of heart, but you've never been faint of heart. You learned self-reliance at eight years old in an empty house. You've survived three recessions, two wars, one pandemic, and countless 'unprecedented' events. You'll manage this too.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly {{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} Americans born in {{BIRTH_YEAR}}—the first year of Generation X. The entire Gen X generation is about 65 million people, making it the smallest of the major cohorts. Sandwiched between 76 million Boomers and 72 million Millennials, you're demographically invisible. You've made that invisibility work for you, but it also means your concerns get ignored.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964): They got the postwar boom; you got its aftermath. They bought houses on single incomes; you needed two. They had pensions; you got 401(k)s and a prayer. They talk about Woodstock; you remember their disco phase, which they'd rather forget. The wealth gap between your generations is real—they accumulated during the expansion, you arrived after the ladder was pulled up. But you also avoided their particular delusions. You never believed you could change the world by holding hands at a concert.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996): You're more self-reliant, less collaborative. They grew up with helicopter parents tracking their every move; you grew up with latchkey freedom and benign neglect. They expect institutions to work for them; you expect institutions to fail. They're comfortable with therapy and emotional processing; you're more likely to bottle it up and power through. They think you're cynical; you think they're naive. You're both probably right.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): You're from different planets. They've never known a world without internet, smartphones, or social media. You remember rotary phones and card catalogs. They're anxious about climate change and authoritarianism; you were anxious about nuclear war and stagflation. Different existential threats, same underlying dread. They think you don't understand technology; you just remember when it didn't exist.

Your life expectancy is around 76-78 years—slightly lower than Boomers' and slightly higher than predictions for later generations. Deaths of despair—suicide, overdose, alcoholism—have hit Gen X harder than the generation before. The 'forgotten generation' label has a dark truth to it. But you've also been resilient in ways that don't get headlines. You adapted to every disruption. You raised kids, managed careers, cared for parents, all while the economy crashed every decade. You didn't complain about it—you just did the work. That's your legacy: competence without fanfare.

year_events: Voting Rights Act signed into law
Watts riots erupted in Los Angeles
Bob Dylan goes electric at Newport
